boardgame.name: Super Nova
boardgame.description:
User Summary

Super Nova was the first commercial release from Big Five Software, a company that would become renowned for high quality adaptations of popular arcade games.

Super Nova was based on the 1979 arcade game Asteroids, and it offers all the same controls as the arcade game: rotate left, rotate right, thrust, fire, and hyperspace.

The gameplay is roughly equivalent to the arcade game. The player controls a ship that must blast through a series of asteroid fields. Each shot that hits causes an asteroid to break into one or more smaller asteroids, with the smallest of the asteroids being vaporized into nothing.

This task is complicated by the occasional appearance of alien spaceships. The most powerful of these, the iconic "Flagship", features a rotating "eye" and fires deadly laser bolts at the player's ship.

The Flagship would go on to star in other Big Five releases, as well as making unofficial appearances in TRS-80 games created others.

boardgame.name: Road Rash
Road Rash (1994/32-bit systems)
Road Rash 3D
Road Rash 3DO
boardgame.description:
Road Rash, often called Road Rash 3D or Road Rash 3DO to distinguish it from the Genesis original of the same name, was originally released on the 3DO, and later for the Sony Playstation, Sega Saturn, and PC. A version for the Super Nintendo was planned for release, but was eventually canceled. The game featured full motion video sequences to advance the plot.

There are five levels altogether, and five courses, all California locales: The City, The Peninsula, Pacific Coast Highway, Sierra Nevada, and Napa Valley. The roads themselves are multi-lane with brief divided road sections.

The object of the game is the same as in previous installments in the series: When all courses are completed without getting "Game Over" or "Busted", in 1st, 2nd or 3rd out of 14th place, the level will increase. Differences affected on tracks are the length and the amount of traffic on the road, with the additions of heavier fines from the police if the player is caught, and a larger reward for completing the track.

The player could choose a character to play as, which came with a specific cash amount and a personal motorcycle. Some of these characters' names come from combatants from the original Genesis releases, such as "Axle" and "Rhonda". The character also had status among his or her fellow bikers, which was accessible after the race. Depending on what the NPC preferred (some liked being hit, some didn't), the other racers would dynamically react to the player depending on how he or she was treated during the races.

Source: Wikipedia, "Road Rash", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

boardgame.name: Gallipoli, 18 March 1915
boardgame.description:
"Gallipoli, 18 March 1915" (published in magazine Schwerpunkt issue #1), is an extension for 3W wargame "Salvo II", and simulates the Allied naval assault on the Turkish forts at the mouth of the Dardanelles.

To be played this extension require some ships counters from Salvo II, and adds for the Entente Allies 4 French and 9 British pre-dreadnoughts. For the Central Powers add rules about shore batteries and mobile minefields.

The victory conditions are for the Entente Allies exit 4 ships across "The Narrows", and for the Central Powers avoid this.

boardgame.name: Galaxy Invasion
boardgame.description:
User Summary

Galaxy Invasion is a Galaxian-style arcade game for the TRS-80. The basic gameplay is the same as the arcade game, with the player's spaceship at the bottom of the screen facing off against waves of diving alien ships.

However, a twist is added to the game with the inclusion of Big Five's signature Flagship alien. At the start of the game there are two Flagships with escorts along the top row of the screen, as in the arcade game. However, as the player advances through the waves of alien ships, more and more Flagships are added to the top row until it is filled with Flagships.

A "Flagship Attack Alert" is displayed once too much time has passed without a Flagship being destroyed. If the alert ends before the player can destroy a Flagship, then all of the Flagships on screen fire their laser bolts, automatically destroying the player's ship.

Galaxy Invasion was the first Big Five game to feature sound effects. These were generated through the TRS-80 cassette output port and could be heard by plugging the cable into an amplified speaker.

boardgame.name: Paths of Storytelling: Vampire
boardgame.description:
From the publisher blurb:

Sometimes my job at White Wolf requires me to dig around in our archives. Mostly I'm looking for a long-lost CD with a particular piece of art or the layout files for an old book, but once in a while I stumble across old contracts, ad copy, and submissions.

A few weeks ago, I ran into this manuscript, in a folder labeled "Paths of Storytelling" and a hand-written note that said "No. Absolutely not. -SW." It looks like something we worked on right around the time of Vampire: The Masquerade Revised. The cover sheet appears to be missing, so I don't know who originally submitted it, or even if it was done by one writer.

Since it's the 20th anniversary of Vampire: The Masquerade, I thought it might be cool to share this strange piece of missing history. I scanned it as best as I could, and we used some old assets from our fiction archive to make a pretty digital version. Enjoy this glimpse into what might have been.

Eddy Webb
World of Darkness Developer

boardgame.name: One of Those Nights
boardgame.description:
Website blurb:
You made your way to the Stalwart's Tavern not long after noon. You could not resist the tales of its fine ale and questionable clientele. Now the tavern is closing and the bouncers are moving everyone out into the street. You left your room at the Wanderer's Inn with the bare essentials, a few small blades and some light armor. But now the streets are dark and the city guards are rarely seen. This is not the time to be wandering around alone. But it is only a few blocks back to the inn; what could happen? Now if you could only remember the way back. You notice that one of the bouncers is approaching and his hand is moving toward the large club hanging from his belt. Suddenly you realize that this is going to be...One of Those Nights.

This solitaire adventure is suitable for a single low to mid-level, humanoid of any type with 25-35 personal adds. You may bring weapons with up to 2 dice and up to 5 points of armor. Limited magic use and missile weapons are also allowed. One of Those Nights is designed to be played using the Tunnels and Trolls game system. You will need the T&T rules to play this game.

boardgame.name: Army Group Narva: Fight without mercy
Army Group Narwa
boardgame.description:
As a continuation of the Leningrad–Novgorod Offensive of January 1944, the Soviet Estonian operation pushed the front westward to the Narva River, aiming to thrust deep into Estonia. Stalin's main strategic goal was a quick recovery of
Estonia as a base for air and seaborne attacks against Finland and an invasion of East Prussia.

The German answer was a stout defence for the possession of the strategically important Narva Isthmus.
Army Group Narwa™ is a board game depicting this event in time.….

The Soviet units established a number of bridgeheads on the opposite bank of the river in February. Subsequent attempts failed to expand their toehold. German counter attacks annihilated the bridgeheads to the north of Narva and reduced the bridgehead south of the town, stabilizing the front until July 1944.

Army Group Narwa™ covers the first three months of the Narva Bridgehead campaign where each turn represents one week.
Army Group Narwa™ is taught in 30 minutes and easy to digest yet a challenge even for the more experienced players. It is built around the same system of rules that shaped Plan West, Königsberg '45 and Stargard Solstice.

The game utilizes a chit-pull system telling you which armies to move.

Game components:
- Book-case box
- 70 x 50 cm map (28 x 20 in)
- 300 die-cut counters
- Game rules
- 2 dice
boardgame.boardgameimplementation: Across The Narva: The Soviet Assault on Estonia, February 1944

boardgame.name: Xtreme Global 1940 Xpansion Mod (fan expansion for Axis & Allies Europe 1940)
boardgame.description:
This is a total Uber Xtreme Xpansion mod for Axis & Allies Europe 1940.

Players play the game like regular Axis & Allies. The game's turns go like this. Instead of playing individual countries for individual players, my rules NOW have all the countries going together at the same time, the incomes are still separate and Japan still controls Japan's income, etc, but NOW ALL players will conduct their turns all at one time, with separate incomes for separate countries and they will all purchase their units at the same time, their turns at the same time, placed on the same "Place Units" board on the game and all playing pieces are color-coded like the regular game. Germany spends income on Germany's pieces and places them in German-held territories with industrial complexes, and Britain does the same, etc on down the line.

United States is NOT at war with anyone and therefore cannot declare war, unless and Axis player declares war on it first or after its 3rd turn for example, like in the real Global game.
The question of ownership of the Dutch territories in the game has been solved. Players will no longer need to land grab the Dutch territories in the wake of Hollland's collapse. Instead, ownership will go to the United Kingdom because they control and are patrons of the Dutch Govt in Exile in London and the Dutch Govt. In Exile is under British control, therefore they belong to the United Kingdom. They will receive the usual bonus for having posession of them. See my PDF document for additonal changes.

The goals of the game are similar to a regular Axis & Allies game. The Axis will capture London, Paris, Kiev, Moscow, and Washington. The Allies will capture the Axis capitals of Tokyo, Berlin, and Rome.

The players are France, Soviet Union, Italy, United Kingdom,(Pacific and Europe) and USA. The goals for the Axis and the Allies are the same as Europe 1940 and Global 1940. Nothing's changed there.

The Allies capture the Axis capitals of Berlin and Rome.

The rules are the same as regular Axis & Allies.

I wanted to expand upon the whole Axis & Allies game by adding more to it. This pack also adds new territories, such as Crimea. Crimea is now important for control of Sea zone 125 as it was in real life. The Black Sea Fleet is also represented with one Battleship and 1 destroyers, and 1 Transports. The Romanian fleet and Russian fleet will inhabit the same waters, but Romania will not be at war until Germany is at war with the Soviet Union because Romania and Hungary are controlled by Germany.

There also new rules regarding the setup.

Germany will receive 1 Major Industrial Complex in Romania to represent the Ploesti oil refinery, which was a large portion of Germany's oil production and gasoline in World War II and 1 Major Industrial Complex for Slovakia-Hungary, which was a large portion of Germany's armaments production that supplied the Germans with the tanks they used to invade France in 1940.

boardgame.name: Spartan: Total Warrior
boardgame.description:
Spartan: Total Warrior is a spin-off action game of the Total War series of games. The game has 14 different levels, in which the player is a lone Spartan warrior, fighting alongside his Greek allies against the Roman Empire, guided by Ares.
While the Total War series has traditionally focused upon historical and legendary scenarios with each instalment, Spartan: Total Warrior is more liberal in its approach to history, drawing elements from the Greek and Roman mythology, and has more in common with games such as God of War. It is also the only instalment in the series thus far to be released for consoles, and not for a personal computer system.

Source: Wikipedia, "Spartan: Total Warrior", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

boardgame.name: Museum Jackpot
boardgame.description:
Published by Pirston Promotions in 2010, the "Museum Jackpot" is a non-elimination type board game. The game comprises of artifacts in the form of 'dinosaur bone sets' or 'relics'. There is no limits of appraisal attached with these artifacts although hold minimum of one appraisal. The player can bid for these throughout the game.

However, the dinosaur bones have one distinct feature that each type of dinosaur, there are three bone set in the form of head, tail and torso, which are gained by players separately and if a player able to acquire all three parts of the same dinosaur, than it comprises one artifact and its value doubled.

The main objective of the game is to collect as many artifacts as possible along with searching for the jackpot while moving through the board. The player can gain extra appraisals and can trade, buy or auction the relics during the game. The appraisals have three level; red, blue and white. When the white appraisal exhausted, the game concludes.

The main strategy includes the removal of 'Fake' appraisal while comprising 'dinosaur bone artifact' as it the only time the 'fake' can be removed. At the end of the game playing having the jackpot appraisal won the cash from the jackpot box along with 'scratch off value card' as well as pre-game ante. The player having the most value of artifacts declared winner, however the player can not win ante, without possessing jackpot.

boardgame.name: Jul-Gonu
boardgame.description:
Jul-Gonu is played on an 4x4 grid (3x3 board on the points). Each player starts with 4 stones on the first row. A stone moves to an orthogonal adjacent empty cell.

Capture is custodian -- if a stone after moving has some enemy stones between itself and another friendly stone then those stones are captured.

A player loses if he has just one stone or is unable to move.

boardgame.name: Squeeze
boardgame.description:
Squeeze and its twin game Swish are non-mancala bead capture games. They are played on a base-5 hex hex board divided in a 37-cells inner area and a 24-cells edge. One player makes an initial setup with three 'hex rooks' of both players on the edge and 19 beads in the inner area. The other player may choose either to move first or the color to play with.

In Squeeze the rooks capture by the custodian method. They may capture both beads and pieces. Simultaneous capture of both is possible, though not as a mixed line, only as two simultaneous captures involving all three rooks. The player who captures 10 or more beads wins.

boardgame.name: Dominant Species: The Card Game
boardgame.description:
15,000 B.C. – a great ice age is ending. Another titanic struggle for global supremacy has unwittingly commenced between the animal species.

Dominant Species: The Card Game is a fast-playing game that abstractly recreates a tiny portion of ancient history: the ponderous rescinding of an ice age and what that entails for the living creatures trying to adapt to the slowly-changing earth.

Players will use six major animal classes – mammal, reptile, bird, amphibian, arachnid or insect – to further their goals in various terrain. Through wily card play, players will strive to become dominant at as many different terrestrial and sea biomes as possible in order to claim valuable victory points: It is survival of the fittest.

All of this leads to the end game – the final descent of the ice age – where the player who has accumulated the most victory points wins the game.

But somebody better become dominant quickly because it's getting mighty warm...

Dominant Species: The Card Game consists of ten rounds of competition, each round occurring on ten of the twelve different Biome cards. The player who starts a competition must choose to either play one Action card or pass.

Action cards consist of animals played to the table as well as events. Animals contribute their Food Chain values towards gaining valuable victory points at the various Biomes, and use their element icons to fight for control of the six Element resource cards. Animals can also sometimes suppress other animals, turning them from Healthy to Endangered, or Endangered to Extinct. Event cards can be powerful one-time effects or ongoing effects that last throughout the round.
Play proceeds clockwise around the table in like fashion until every player has passed consecutively or when any one player has passed with an empty hand. At that point Element cards and the current Biome card are scored, with victorious players recording their gains on the Victory Point Track. If the competition is at a Tundra, one or more dominant players will advance one space on the Survival Track.

The current Biome card as well as all played Action cards are then discarded, and a new Biome card brought into play. Finally, each player draws (and perhaps discards) new Action cards based on his position on the Survival Track, and a new competition round begins. Play proceeds from Biome to Biome in like fashion until the game ends and a winner is determined.

Reimplements

Dominant Species

From their own description:

OBJECT OF THE GAME: The object of the game is to build high scoring number sequences cross-cube fashion with as many cubes as possible before the timer runs out. The player who exercises the greatest skill and strategy in forming and locating number combinations on the playing board to best advantage will attain the highest score.

This is the "Original Version"-(until such time yet another is discovered to refute such), that later kinds were based upon. It includes 15 six-sided dice with six-(6) varying numerals configurations upon those, to include some combination derived from the numbers between 1 to 15 upon their facile sides. There is also a "Sandtimer" attachment piece, to affix it onto a corner of the plastic GAME board/dice tray. Their "playing area" is comprised of an inset, plastic 9 X 9 grid in a "Scrabble-ish" demeanor, with *Special* placement spots denoting Double or Triple *Score*, as well with numbered sort from #4 to #15 arranged sequentially into an arrayed 'diamond pattern' 2-spots away from the center, as the middle one is their black START spot. boardgame.name: Aether Captains: Triad
boardgame.description:
3 games innovatively using 1 deck of 54 custom cards, all set in the steampunk-themed Aether Captains game world.

Players supply 5d6 to share and 24 eurocube sized markers per player. All the games are designed to share components and be able to be played quickly by 2 players in a compact space. Deck includes all cards to play each game, cards which are the game boards, and rules. Designed for print and play fans of Aether Captains (printable on standard 8.5" x 11' paper), also available as an Artscow order.

The Games:

Intrigue (27 cards including rules): a 2 player game of area control across the city states of Arkady, using 24 eurocube style markers per player. Players take on the role of Grand Council members, vying for influence in the city states. Players use groups of matching cards to place 1-3 markers in each city state during their turns, trying for a majority, or can use cards to remove an opponent's influence. The game is played in 2 rounds, scoring each round, and takes 10-20 minutes.

Zeppelin Derby (12 cards including rules): a simple 2 player race game in the skies over Thoia. Players roll 5d6 and use cards as roll modifiers to race across a 3 card course. Cards include Dirty Tricks and Engineering bonuses. 5-10 minutes.

Celinian Trader (14 cards including rules): a pick up and deliver style game of trade on the Celinian Sea for 1 or 2 players. Needed are 14 eurocube style markers per player and 5d6. Players fill their holds with different types of goods - copper, glass, coal and linen - as they sail from port to port buying and selling goods, amassing their fortunes. The game is played over 4 rounds whose length is determined by a series of events both players are subject to. Different values for buying and selling are set by a Trade Market that changes prices from round to round. Competing for victory points, players may also purchase upgrades to their ships. This game is also suitable for solitaire play and takes 20-30 minutes.

All three games are designed to be quickly learned, easy to play and fun.

boardgame.name: De Pre Historie Quiz
boardgame.description:
De Pre Historie Quiz is a Trivia game played with a cd containing a huge amount of music fragments en about 200 questions about music hits. The first one to complete his compact disc playboard is winner.

Every player has his own compact disc made of 8 pieces, like slices of a pie. There are 8 categories of questions and you have to get one question correct in every category to complete your compact disc and win the game.
The 8 categories are:
Music Title -> where the player must name the title of a song
Music Artist -> where the player must name the artist of a song
Music Country -> where the player must name the country of origin of the artist
Music Title + Artist -> where the player must name both title and artist of the song
Trivia Time -> where the player must know the year a certain event happened
Trivia Name -> where the player must name the main person in a certain event
Trivia Country -> where the player must name the place where a certain event happened
Trivia Name and Country -> where the player must name both the main person as the place of a certain event

There are two dice: One with the options Music or Trivia. And another one with the 4 subcategories. The dice decide what fragment/song is played and what question to answer.

boardgame.name: Dan-Chi
boardgame.description:
Dan-Chi contains 32 dual sided playing pices and a double sided board to play 6 different games (different variants)

Contents: 8 Red-White Guard Counters
8 White-Green Guard Counters
8 Green-Black Guard Counters
8 Black-Red Guard Counters
1 Double Sided Board - Front Board (6 by 6 square grid)
- Back Board (7 by 7 square grid, with center square missing)
Rules Booklet
Overview Leaflet.

The aim of the game is to get two of your guards onto a matching pair of Chi symbols printed on the board. The first player to do so wins the round and scores points based on the symbol matched, the guards lost and the opponents guards eliminated. As pairs of symbols need capturing, if an any time a player has only one guard left they are eliminated - leading to a secondary win condition.

In each turn a player moves two guards eliminating (jumping over and removing) any opponets within reach. Chi symbols can only be occupied if capturing is not possible. There are 6 games, but as the rules (and aim) for each are identicle these seem to be more like variants rather than fully fledged games.
Due to the mechanic of capturing these games play similar to checkers but the Chi matching alters the strategy quite well.

The six games are called: Tae Kwon Do (2 Players - Front Board), Aikido (4 Players - Back Board), Kung-Fu (4 Players - Front Board), Karate (2 Players - Back Board), Judo (2 Players - Front Board) and Jujitsu (2 Players - Back Board).

The theme of the game is martial arts, however this is not crutial and seems tacked on. The identical game would work, for example, with a space theme or a roman warrior theme. As with all abstracts the theme is not that important.

boardgame.name: Bingo Ball (Chart Football)
boardgame.description:
"This game is played in pairs and is enjoyable for 2 players as it is for 10"

A game inspired by Battleships. Each player gets a card with two football pitches marked on it. One is for 'Your score sheet", the other marked as 'Opponents score sheet". You keep your card secret at all times. Each pitch is divided up into 10 squares across and 6 squares down. The rows across are represented by the letters A to F. The columns down are marked 1 to 10. So every square can be chosen by giving a letter and a number A7 or C2, for example. The idea is to trace a line from Row F up to row A, without running into a T square which represents a tackle.

boardgame.name: Napoleon's War II: The Gates of Moscow
boardgame.description:
The Napoleon's War Series are games that give players the French Army of Napoleon against the foes of France from 1796 -1815. Each game includes battles that have their own custom game boards, plastic figures representing the infantry, artillery, and cavalry with counters representing the special units, leaders, etc. Each battle within the game is playable in 1 to 2 hours. The game uses the Hold the Line command action point (CAP) system. Also added is a new optional chit pull system that is ideal for solitaire play. The game highlights the strengths and weaknesses of the different nationalities and units, as well as the various formations of each. The second game in the series is Napoleon's War Volume II: The Gates of Moscow with custom game boards of Marengo, Austerlitz, Aspern-Essling, and Borodino.

Plastic pieces in blue, white, and green portray the French, Austrian, and Russian armies.
This game is a sequel to Napoleon's War: The 100 Days

boardgame.name: The 3rd Birthday
The Third Birthday
ザ・サード バースデイ
boardgame.description:
In the far future -

Unknown creatures suddenly appear on the planet, and begin multiplying rapidly. They feed on humans, and once their food supply is gone, they travel to the past for more. Now here they are - in the present. No one knows what they are and how they came to be. These powerful creatures are dubbed the "Twisted" because of their irregular, spiral shape. In response, the government creates a Counter Twisted Investigation team - the CTI. They declare a state of emergency and play their final card.

The Overdrive Investigation -

The CTI is allowed a special type of investigation - one that allows the changing of the past to better the present. The only candidate compatible with the system is Aya, the protagonist and a CTI special agent. She wakes up with no recollection of her past, and is tortured by nightmares. And yet, she takes the investigation head on, in an effort to find out the truth of who she really is.

boardgame.name: Dungeon Shift
boardgame.description:
"You awaken in a dimly-lit room with no memory of how you came to be here. As you groggily rise to your feet, you notice a sword, a scroll, a rope, and a lock pick have been laid out next to you. Dazed and confused, you pluck the scroll off the ground, hoping it will explain things. No such luck. It appears to be a magic scroll, used for summoning a wolf spirit.

You hear a clattering behind you, and the hairs on the back of your neck prickle. You turn to see a crazed-looking goblin shuffling towards you with a rusty scimitar in its hands. Quickly, you snatch up the sword. The goblin lunges at you. You clumsily block its attack, then thrust forward and impale the foam-mouthed creature. It slumps to the ground, dead.

You have no idea how you got here or why you are here. But you have a few tools at your disposal, and you are going to find a way out."

Dungeon Shift is a print-and-play solo dungeon-crawling card game. The player begins the game with four cards from the Equipment deck and must use those cards to overcome the various challenges presented by the Rooms, Monsters, and Traps in the Obstacle deck. Cross chasms, pick locks, disarms traps, and fight monsters, all the while hoping to not run out of equipment as you try to escape from the dungeon!

Once you have drawn all the cards in the Obstacle deck, you win. You may also complete a Victory condition presented by the Obstacle cards, but be warned, these Victory conditions are extremely difficult. If you run out of Equipment or become "stuck" with no way to advance, you lose!

While expanding on the concepts of Dream Shift, Dungeon Shift is not simply a re-themed version of the first game in the Shift series. It adds introduces new concepts and further explores the potential of the Shift design space.

boardgame.name: Chase the Enemy
boardgame.description:
The board is like a chess board but 9 x 9 instead of 8 x 8. This is really a Draughts variant. All pieces start on the black squares and cannot jump or move on to a white square.
One player is the Attack and the other the Defence.
Pieces are assigned as sea-going vessels such as a Battleship, a U-Boat and even a Sea Plane.
The object for the Attack player is to capture as many vessels as possible. The pieces are assigned a point value. The Defence tries to get as many vessels into a Harbour square, where they are safe from attack.

boardgame.name: Mage Noir
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

The 1940s began and ended with war. The war that opened the decade was fought with bombs and guns, and ended with a weapon more powerful and horrific than anything the world has seen. In the meantime, the citizens of the United States rebuild their society. The war didn't touch the country directly, as it did Europe, but the losses were palpable all the same. Millions of American men went to war, and thousands upon thousands did not return. Many that did returned changed and haunted, and the music and Hollywood glamour of the rest of the decade could not drown out those nightmares.

Would this new Fallen World have a place for mages, or had Sleepers outgrown any chance of Awakening?

This PDF includes:

A brief historical look at America in the 1940s, from a mage's perspective.
Player and Storyteller advice on chronicles set in this time period.
A Storytelling Adventure System story set in the 1940s, complete with a pre-generated cabal.
A new legacy: the Quiescent.

boardgame.name: Karous
Raven
カラス
boardgame.description:
Karous (カラス, karasu, "raven") is a video game by Milestone Inc. intended for the Sega NAOMI. The game is a vertical scrolling shooter, similar in this fashion to Radilgy. A Dreamcast version was released in March 2007. It's the last official game released for the Dreamcast in Japan.

The weapon system is based on Radio Allergy, but it uses a unique D.F.S. bomb system.

Bombs can be used when SP gauge is full. When a bomb is activated, a barrier surrounds the player, which can damage enemies within the barrier. For the duration of bomb activation, the player is invulnerable. Enemies destroyed by the barrier provide more experience points to the player.

The player's shot, sword, shield can be upgraded by using experience items dropped from enemies, with a maximum of 100 levels. Weapon levels also act as score multipliers.

Source: Wikipedia, "Karous", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

boardgame.name: Super Street Fighter IV: 3D Edition
boardgame.description:
Packed with 35 playable characters, bonus stages and cinematic Ultra combos,
Super Street Fighter® IV: 3D Edition expands the action by allowing you to fight your friends
around the world using Wi-Fi.
New to the franchise are the figurine mode, which utilizes the Street Pass feature to add a collectible meta-game, and the 3D over-the-shoulder camera option that takes fighting to new depths. For those new to the franchise, a simple mode has been added allowing players to pull off challenging moves with a single touch of the screen.


Online/Local WiFi Multiplayer - Fight your friends around the world or in the same room with the only title to utilize the full capabilities of Nintendo’s online network at launch
35 Playable Characters - Play as one of a huge array of fighters ranging from classic world warriors like Ryu, Ken, Guile and Chun Li to the newly added Hakan and Juri
Figurine Mode - The collectible meta-game features figurines of iconic characters in a brand-new addition to the Street Fighter® franchise. When passing by another 3DS owner, your chosen figurines will automatically battle via Street Pass. Next time you play the game you can view the results and collect your loot!
3D Mode - A new over-the-shoulder camera option has been added, offering an exciting new perspective on the action
Game Sharing - Play a game with a friend using the ever-popular Ryu, even when they don’t have a cartridge!
Be A Spectator * With the Spectator Mode, use your own 3DS to watch your friends battle it out live
Lite/Pro Control Modes - By utilizing a customizable touch screen interface, two new optional control schemes have been added to allow new players to pull off challenging moves with ease (Lite) and veterans to better access button combinations such as throws and three punches (Pro)


Source: The Publisher Website.

Asphalt 3D is racing as you’ve never experienced before! Full stereoscopic 3D graphics and authentically modeled licensed supercars make this the most realistic, immersive racing experience yet. In Asphalt 3D, you’ll power over 40 high-performance vehicles and race through 17 exotic locations in both career and multiplayer modes.

boardgame.description:
Underworld Couriers is a pick-up and deliver game with a twist.

Players are couriers contracted to carry illicit goods around a map of the globe.

Using a timeline, players must plan the most effective mode of travel between pick-up point and delivery location (air, road, rail or ship). Each of these types of transport takes travels at a different speed, costs various amounts and entails certain risks (passing through customs).

Successfully completing a delivery will earn the player Notoriety and money. But be careful not to get caught or you risk a stint in jail.

The most Notorious player at the end of the game is the winner.

boardgame.name: Frontline: Guadalcanal
boardgame.description:
Take the fight to the Pacific!

Frontline is a tactical WWII ground combat card game for 1 to 4 players. This second game in the series covers small unit action during the battle for Guadalcanal.

Each player commands a squad of 4 to 10 American or Japanese soldiers and vehicles. Each card represents one soldier or vehicle. Each unit has inherent actions each turn including moving and attacking with different modes of fire. An action card deck enhances basic actions, and provides units with spur of the moment options.

The game uses counters to illustrate vital game information such as wounds, range, ammo, command, and morale. The range system is easy to use and simulates the movement of forces on the battlefield.

Frontline can also be played solitaire using the enemy Tactic cards. These cards give general, specific, and conditional orders to the enemy troops based on the current battlefield situation.

You can create battles by purchasing your starting forces, playing pre-made scenarios, or using the balanced randomized engagement rules.

Scheduled Components:
165 Full color cards (63mm x 88mm)
1 Full color counter sheet
Rulebook (Full Color)

Complexity:
Low to Moderate

boardgame.name: Aquelarre: A Medieval Demonic Roleplaying Game
Aquelarre: Juego de rol demoníaco medieval
boardgame.description:
user summary

Third Edition from Aquelarre, the medieval demonic roleplaying game.
This new edition maintains all the spirit and flavor of classic. Add new mechanics to salve game situations. The book is presented in color in the style of illuminated manuscripts and books. Has been published with two different covers.

In spanish:
La tercera edición de Aquelarre, el juego de rol medieval demoniaco.
Veinte años después de su primera edición, vuelve Aquelarre más completo y documentado que nunca. Esta nueva edición mantiene todo el espíritu y sabor del Aquelarre clásico y presenta al mismo tiempo nuevas mecánicas para solventar mejor algunas situaciones de juego. Más medieval y más demoníaco que nunca, el libro se presenta en una cuidada edición a todo color imitando el estilo de los códices y libros miniados. Existen dos cubiertas diferentes del mismo libro.

Carretas repletas de cadáveres resbalan por las calles embarradas de una ciudad deshabitada. Monjes copistas escriben en silencio en frías salas de monasterio. El martillo cae una y otra vez sobre el metal al rojo en el taller del herrero. Flores de fragante olor se abren en los jardines privados de la corte. Adustos y callados soldados marchan por caminos polvorientos en busca de enemigos, sean infieles o no. Es el mundo de la Edad Media, el que conocieron nuestros antepasados, el que conformó nuestro presente.

Pero más allá de lo humano, en lo más profundo de los bosques, en la cueva más solitaria, en la celda más recóndita, en lo más oculto del corazón humano, viven las leyendas. Los demonios pisan castillos, los duendes se ocultan en la floresta, los alquimistas utilizan hechizos y las brujas ríen y ríen alrededor de la hoguera, en un claro de un bosque bañado por la luz de la luna, mientras el demonio, sentado entre ellas, levanta su cabeza de macho cabrío y te sonríe, directamente a ti, lector.

boardgame.name: Lakers vs Celtics and the NBA Playoffs
boardgame.description:
Lakers versus Celtics and the NBA Playoffs was a video game released first in 1989 for MS-DOS-compatible PCs and later adapted for consoles when released in early 1991 for the Sega Mega Drive/Sega Genesis. The game was highly successful; it was the first game endorsed by the NBA and was the first to contain multiple NBA stars and teams in one game. As the title suggested, the game was launched due to the success of the 1980s Celtics–Lakers rivalry. Established stars you can play in the game include Larry Bird, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar (only on the computer version, not the Genesis version), Magic Johnson, Michael Jordan, and Patrick Ewing.

Source: Wikipedia, "Lakers versus Celtics and the NBA Playoffs", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

boardgame.name: Crashbot Derby!
boardgame.description:
Welcome to Crashbot Derby! In this board game, you play as one of 8 superpowered robots competing in the ultimate mechanized demolition derby! Attack your enemies with wild weapons, treacherous traps, or just by crashing into them! Don’t get sidetracked, though: the object is to cross the finish line first!

Gameplay

You're in a race with up to 5 other players; your goal is to complete 3 laps (enter a checkpoint space 6 times, essentially) first. Along the way, you may step on special spaces that will give you sparks (the "currency" of this game), cards, or allow you to activate your unique Robopower!

On your turn you may do these things:
- roll a 6-sided die 2 times
- spend sparks if you have them
- play cards if you have them
You can do these in any order. You can spend sparks
or play cards between die rolls.

Of course, racing is only part of it: the other part is fighting! You can attack your opponents with the cards in your hands , which usually represent a gizmo you can use offensively. You can also spend 3 red sparks to shoot opponents... and of course, as the name implies, you can crash into them!

Players are never eliminated from the game, they continue racing until a winner crosses the finish line!

boardgame.description:
45 cards, in four suits - Diamonds, Stars, Circles and Squares. The game is inspired by the playing card game of Hearts or Black Maria. This is a trick taking game where you lose points if you 'collect' a trick containg Stars or the 3 Witch Cards. When one player has a score of 200 points against him, the game ends, and the player with the lowest score wins.

This was the first card game published by Castell. Belisha, Progress, and Speed were all part of this new range.

In 1951, the game was reissued with slightly different rules and new card illustrations, and a new name:
Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs

boardgame.description:
The dealer shuffles the orange stuff-cards and spreads them all face down. Place the blue stuff-cards face down in a deck to the side of Madame Blueberry's pile of orange cards. The youngest player starts.

The first player draws a card from the orange pile and places it face up in front of him/her.
If a Thankful card with a heart is drawn, discard all of your stuff cards and the next player goes.
When an orange stuff card is drawn, put it in front of you. Even if it's a card you don't need.
If a salesman card is drawn with a $ sign, the player must draw 2 blue stuff cards. Place those stuff cards in front of you and discard the salesman card.
If the Madame Blueberry card is drawn, keep on drawing until you get a Thankful card. Put back all the other stuff cards, including the ones you already had.

The first player who gets four thankful cards to make a happy heart wins the game.

boardgame.name: It's a Goal
It's a Goal!
boardgame.description:
A card game with 44 cards, 22 representing the First Division and 22 representing the Second Division.
Players try to score goals by playing cards which have number on them. You add up the cards played and if they total 120 or more, a goal is scored (you have covered the distance from your goalk to your opponent's goal). There are special cards that provide interaction - Goalkeepers, Penalty Cards and Obstruction Cards.

boardgame.name: Gulliver's Travels
boardgame.description:
A movie-related game but not Disney this time. This game made use of scenes from the cartoon film by Max Fleischer at Paramount studios. Published anonymously by Pepys because they didn't want to risk losing their good-will with Disney.
44 cards, each with an illustration and a word. Players must add a card to the centre of the table in their turn. Only the word on the card added is important. It must make sense and contribute to a proper sentence. When the 7th or more card is added and a sentence is finished, the player playing the last card to the sentence takes the 'trick'.
